items.text: The **Colville National Forest** is a U.S.

National Forest located in northeastern [[LINK|lang_en|Washington_(U.S._state)|Washington]] state. It is bordered on the west by the [[LINK|lang_en|Okanogan_National_Forest|Okanogan National Forest]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Kaniksu_National_Forest|Kaniksu National Forest]] to the east. The forest itself also contains [[LINK|lang_en|Little_Pend_Oreille_National_Wildlife_Refuge|Little Pend Oreille National Wildlife Refuge]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Lake_Roosevelt_National_Recreation_Area|Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area]].

The forest encompasses a mountainous area consisting of the [[LINK|lang_en|Kettle_River_Range|Kettle River]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Selkirk_Mountains|Selkirk]] mountain ranges, and the upper reaches of the [[LINK|lang_en|Columbia_River|Columbia River]]. Wildlife include [[LINK|lang_en|Grizzly_bear|grizzly]] and [[LINK|lang_en|American_black_bear|black]] bears, [[LINK|lang_en|Northwestern_wolf|timber wolves]], [[LINK|lang_en|Bighorn_sheep|bighorn sheep]], [[LINK|lang_en|North_American_cougar|cougars]], [[LINK|lang_en|Bald_eagle|bald eagles]], [[LINK|lang_en|Canada_lynx|Canadian lynxes]], [[LINK|lang_en|Moose|moose]], [[LINK|lang_en|North_American_beaver|beavers]], [[LINK|lang_en|Loon|loons]], and the last remaining herd of [[LINK|lang_en|Caribou|caribou]] in the lower 48 US states.

The forest has a total area of 1.1 million [[LINK|lang_en|Acre|acres]] (1 718.75 sq mi, or 4 451.54 kmÂ²). A 1993 Forest Service study estimated that the extent of [[LINK|lang_en|Old_growth|old growth]] in the Forest was 212,488 acres (85,991 ha). [[CITE|6|http://www.fs.fed.us/land/staff/lar/LAR2011/LAR2011_Book_A5.pdf]] In descending order of forestland area it is located in parts of [[LINK|lang_en|Ferry_County,_Washington|Ferry]], [[LINK|lang_en|Pend_Oreille_County,_Washington|Pend Oreille]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Stevens_County,_Washington|Stevens]] counties. The forest headquarters is located in [[LINK|lang_en|Colville,_Washington|Colville, Washington]]. There are local [[LINK|lang_en|National_Park_Ranger|ranger]] district offices located in [[LINK|lang_en|Kettle_Falls,_Washington|Kettle Falls]], [[LINK|lang_en|Metaline_Falls,_Washington|Metaline Falls]], [[LINK|lang_en|Newport,_Washington|Newport]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Republic,_Washington|Republic]].

Most of the [[LINK|lang_en|Salmo-Priest_Wilderness|Salmo-Priest Wilderness]] lies within the forest, while its southeastern portion extends into [[LINK|lang_en|Kaniksu_National_Forest|Kaniksu National Forest]].

The [[LINK|lang_en|Pacific_Northwest_National_Scenic_Trail|Pacific Northwest National Scenic Trail]] passes through the Colville National Forest. It enters the forest on the east side within the [[LINK|lang_en|Salmo-Priest_Wilderness|Salmo-Priest Wilderness]], crosses the Pend Oreille at [[LINK|lang_en|Boundary_Dam|Boundary Dam]], passes through Leadpoint and [[LINK|lang_en|Northport,_Washington|Northport]], then traverses the Kettle Range and exits the Colville near [[LINK|lang_en|Republic|Republic]]. The **Sullivan Lake Trail**, designated a [[LINK|lang_en|National_Recreation_Trail|National Recreation Trail]] in 1978, runs 4.3 miles (6.9 km) between two campgrounds in the forest. [[CITE|3|http://americantrails.org/NRTDatabase/trailDetail.php?recordID=605]]
